snippet: A return of sectarian violence in Iraq’s capital appears to have been prompted by the rebuilding of a religious shrine bombed in 2006.
abstract: Controversy over control of a religious shrine takes a new violent turn when a suicide car bomber strikes an important Shiite religious office in central Baghdad, leaving at least 18 dead and nearly 125 wounded; nature of attacks lays bare the sectarian disputes that still poison Iraqi society.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and YASIR GHAZI
byline.contributor: Employees of The New York Times contributed reporting from Baghdad and Samarra, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: A return of sectarian violence in Iraq’s capital appears to have been prompted by the rebuilding of a religious shrine bombed in 2006.

headline.seo: Bid to Rebuild Askariya Shrine Leads to Bombing in Baghdad
headline.main: Violence Spreads in Struggle for Baghdad Shrine
headline.print_headline: Violence Spreads In Struggle For Shrine
